questions.q: Based on the formal definition provided in the lecture, which of the following best describes an array?
questions.explanation: An array is defined as a contiguous area of memory consisting of equal-size elements indexed by contiguous integers.
options: A contiguous area of memory consisting of equal-size elements indexed by contiguous integers.
A collection of elements of varying sizes stored in non-contiguous memory locations.
A set of data points linked by pointers where each element points to the next location.
A group of equal-size elements stored in random memory addresses with non-integer indices.

questions.q: What is the Big-O time complexity for accessing an arbitrary element in an array?
questions.explanation: Arrays provide constant-time access to any element.
options: O(n)
O(log n)

questions.q: In the provided formula for 1D array address calculation, what does the variable 'i' represent?
questions.explanation: In the memory address formula, 'i' represents the index of the element for which the address is being calculated.
options: The index of the specific element being accessed.
The total number of elements in the array.
The memory size of each individual element.
The starting memory address of the entire array.

questions.q: According to the lecture, what is the time complexity for adding or removing an element at the beginning of an array?
questions.explanation: Adding or removing an element at the beginning or middle of an array requires linear time, O(n), because other elements must be shifted.
options: O(n)
O(log n)
O(n log n)

questions.q: Which operation can be performed in constant time O(1) in a standard array?
questions.explanation: The lecture notes specify that adding or removing at the end of an array takes constant time O(1).
options: Adding an element to the end.
Adding an element to the middle.
Removing an element from the beginning.
Inserting an element at index 0.

questions.q: A 2D array calculation is shown as: $array_addr + elem_size * ((3 - 1) * 6 + (4 - 1))$. If this represents the element at (3,4), what does the value '6' likely represent?
questions.explanation: In multi-dimensional array address calculation, the row offset is typically multiplied by the number of columns (the width of the row) to find the correct memory location.
options: The number of columns in each row.
The total number of elements in the array.
The memory address of the first element.
The size of each individual element in bytes.

questions.q: How does Column-major order store elements differently than Row-major order?
questions.explanation: Row-major order lists elements row by row (e.g., (1,1), (1,2)), while Column-major order lists them column by column (e.g., (1,1), (2,1)).
options: It stores elements of the same column in contiguous memory rather than elements of the same row.
It stores elements in a random order to optimize search speed.
It uses non-contiguous memory blocks for each column.
It allows elements of different sizes to be stored in the same array.

questions.q: If you need to remove an element from the middle of an array of size 'n', what is the resulting time complexity?
questions.explanation: Removing an element from an arbitrary location (like the middle) takes linear time O(n).
options: O(n)
O(log n)

questions.q: In the context of multi-dimensional arrays, what coordinates would follow (1,1), (1,2), and (1,3) if the array is stored in Row-major order?
questions.explanation: In Row-major order, elements are stored sequentially by row, so (1,4) follows (1,3) in a row with at least 4 columns.

questions.q: What is the calculation for the memory address of the i-th element of a 1D array that starts at first_index?
questions.explanation: The memory address is found by adding the offset (element size times the number of elements from the start) to the base array address.
options: array_addr + elem_size * (i - first_index)
array_addr + i
array_addr + elem_size * i
elem_size * (i + first_index)
